ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: The Development and Application of an Integrated VAR Process Model
Die Entwicklung und Anwendung eines integrierten Prozessmodells für Vakuumlichtbogen-Umschmelzen (VAR)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The VAR ingot has been the focus of several modelling efforts over the years with the result that the thermal regime in the ingot can be simulated quite realistically. Such models provide important insight into the solidification of the ingot but present some significant challenges to the casual user such as a process engineer. To provide the process engineer with a tool to assist in the development of a melt practice, a comprehensive model of the complete VAR process has been developed. A radiation heat transfer simulation of the arc has been combined with electrode and ingot models to develop a platform which accepts typical operating variables (voltage, current, and gap) together with process parameters (electrode size, crucible size, orientation, water flow, etc.) as input data. The output consists of heat flow distributions and solidification parameters. Utilizing heat balance information generated by the model, the effects of electrode-crucible orientation and arc gap have been explored with regard to the formation of ingot segregation defects.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: Der VAR-Blockherstellung steht seit Jahren im Mittelpunkt von mehreren Modellierungsansätzen mit dem Ergebnis, dass das thermische Regime im Block sehr realistisch simuliert werden kann. Solche Modelle liefern wichtige Einblicke in die Erstarrung der Blöcke, stellen aber einige bedeutende Herausforderungen an den Benutzer in der industriellen Praxis, wie zum Beispiel dem Prozessingenieur. Um dem Prozessingenieur ein Werkzeug zur Verfügung zu stellen, das ihn bei der Entwicklung seiner praktischen Erfahrung für das Schmelzen unterstützt, wurde ein umfassendes Modell des kompletten VAR-Prozesses entwickelt. Ein Simulationsmodel der Wärmübertragung durch Strahlung des Lichtbogens wurde mit Elektroden- und Block-Modellen kombiniert. Damit wurde eine Plattform entwickelt, die die typischen Betriebsgrößen (Spannung, Strom und Lichtbogenspalt) gemeinsam mit Prozessparametern (Elektrodengröße, Tiegelgröße, Ausrichtung, Wasserfluss, etc.) als Inputdaten übernimmt. Der Output besteht aus Wärmestromverteilungen und Erstarrungsparametern. Mit den Modellergebnissen aus der Wärmebilanzberechnung wurden die Auswirkungen der räumlichen Orientierung des Elektrodentiegels und des Lichtbogenspaltes im Hinblick auf die Bildung von Seigerungen im Block untersucht.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The development of a VAR melt practice for a new alloy or different sized ingot often utilizes a prior practice for a similar alloy or similar sized ingot as a starting point. Following multiple melt trials and evaluations, a successful practice can usually be found, although it may not necessarily be the most optimum practice. The cost of performing multiple optimization trials combined with the urgency of qualifying a successful practice to permit commercialization of the product often preclude an exhaustive investigation of the many possible practices. Moreover, altering a qualified melt practice can be exceedingly costly. To this end, the use of mathematical models to provide additional insight into the solidification conditions during casting can assist tremendously in arriving at an optimum melt practice without an excessive number of trials.

Such models have evolved significantly over the years as improvements in computing power have permitted the use of more advanced numerical algorithms to simulate increasingly detailed physical phenomena. Due to the sophistication of these models, their use generally depends on individuals who have a significant modelling background as opposed to a casual user such as a process engineer. The models also require thermophysical property data and boundary condition data which may not be readily available to a process engineer and can consume significant computing resources especially for the more sophisticated models. Finally, the models may not accept input data in the form of operating parameters as would be specified by a process engineer. Consequently, from a process engineer’s point of view, there is a need which would be filled by a model of the complete VAR process.

Section1.Heading: Model Development
Section1.Para: The VAR process model (Figure 1) combines three separate models for the electrode, the arc, and the ingot into an integrated model which accepts input parameters that are specified as operating variables—voltage, either current or melt rate, and gap. The electrode model consists of a one-dimensional conduction model to calculate the axial temperature gradient in the electrode. From the axial temperature profile, heat conduction into the electrode and heat losses from the lateral electrode surface can be calculated and incorporated into the arc model.

The arc model developed by Ballantyne [1] is key to linking the electrode and ingot models and is based on an electrical analog for radiative heat exchange [3] between the surfaces which bound the arc—the electrode bottom surface, the ingot top surface, and the crown/crucible wall. The previous model [1] has been extended to include multiple concentric rings in the arc such that a radial distribution of energy can be specified in the gap arc.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Physical configuration of the VAR process model

Section1.Para: The radiation network for this modified model is shown in Figure 2. The input heat distribution in the gap arc may be specified by defining the heat flux distribution as uniform, Gaussian, or linearly increasing from edge to center of the arc. The side arc heat input is defined as a percentage of the total heat input to the system. The former model has also been modified based on the assumption that radiation from the gap arc does not impinge directly on the crucible wall, but rather on the crown that forms above the ingot. Radiation from the side arc impinges on the lateral electrode wall and crucible wall above the crown. The interior surface temperatures of the crown and crucible are estimated iteratively from the radiative heat flux and the thermal resistance from the crown to the crucible wall to the cooling water with the inclusion of helium cooling, forced convection, and boiling water heat transfer.

Geometric parameters relating electrode size and weight, arc gap, and crucible dimensions are used to calculate electrode pipe, final ingot height and weight, and the view factors which determine the radiative exchange between the appropriate surfaces. Emissivities for the various surfaces involved in the radiation exchange must be specified but, once defined, should vary very little from case to case.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Modified network analysis incorporating multiple arc and ingot nodes with the electrode, crown and crucible wall

Section1.Para: The elements in red (Figure 2) constitute non-radiative terms in the electrical network. The assumption is made that the droplets leave the electrode tip at the liquidus temperature and are superheated to a specified temperature as they pass through the arc.

The ingot model is based on a two-dimensional finite difference model which incorporates temperature-dependent thermophysical properties and boundary conditions. Prior to each iteration, the electrode and arc models are solved to calculate updated heat flows to the top surface of the ingot.

Section1.Heading: Model Execution
Section1.Para: The model utilizes a Windows-type interface (Figure 3) with results being written to an ASCII (TXT) file, to comma-separated value (CSV) files, and to visual toolkit (VTK) files. Execution times are very fast, typically being 10–15 seconds.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: User interface for VAR process model

Section1.Para: Input parameters include specification of a melt profile either as voltage-current-gap, or voltage-melt rate-gap as a function of either % of the final ingot length or as a function of the remaining electrode weight. Depending on whether the current or melt rate is specified, the model will utilize an iterative procedure to determine the missing factor—melt rate or current respectively.

Section1.Heading: Effect of Input Heat Distribution
Section1.Para: The input heat distribution is specified as an edge to center heat flux distribution. The choices are uniform, Gaussian, or linearly increasing. Previous modelling studies [2] have made the assumption that the heat flux distribution to the ingot top surface is Gaussian, so it is interesting to examine the heat distribution to the ingot which results from uniform and Gaussian heat flux distributions in the arc.

Figures 4 and 5 show two input flux distributions for the same total power input. A Gaussian flux distribution in the arc (Figure 4) is reduced to a much lower, more uniform flux at the ingot surface due to the multiple reflections between the electrode and the ingot surfaces. A uniform flux in the arc (Figure 5) is reduced to a much lower, but still uniform flux at the ingot surface. A comparison of these two ingot fluxes (Figure 6) themselves reveals that the Gaussian flux retains the Gaussian shape but the maximum to minimum ratio at the ingot surface is much lower than it is in the arc distribution.

Section1.Heading: Effect of Changing Fill Ratio
Section1.Para: One of the outcomes of the process model is the calculation of an overall heat balance of the process at any specific instant. A typical heat balance in graphical form (Figure 7) displays the energy input in the gap and side arcs, the various energy losses, and the internal energy exchanges between various components. A comparison of heat balances for two different melting conditions can yield insight into the effect of the appropriate variables on the process behaviour.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Instantaneous energy balance for the VAR process

Section1.Para: One such comparison involves the effect of a changing annulus as would arise due to a tapered electrode melting into a tapered crucible (Figure 8).

Melt geometries for invert (opposing tapers) and upright (coinciding tapers) melts of a typical 425–440 mm diameter electrode into a 497–515 mm diameter crucible are summarized in Figures 9 and 10. In the case of the invert melt, regardless of the tapers, the annulus always decreases as the ingot height increases. For the upright melt, the annulus may increase or decrease as the ingot is formed, depending on the actual tapers.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Changing melt geometry at the melt interface for an invert melt
Changing melt geometry at the melt interface for an upright melt orientation

Section1.Para: Regardless of which configuration is used, the result is most likely to be an annulus which varies throughout the melting operation. The consequences of this changing annulus can be predicted from an examination of the changing heat balance of the VAR process throughout the melt. For the case of a melt with a decreasing annulus at a constant melt rate, a comparison of the heat balance at a 20 % ingot length with that at 100 % ingot length (Figure 11) shows an increase in melting efficiency (reduced specific power consumption) and a declining input power (current) requirement due to the declining fill ratio.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Energy balance at 20 % and 100 % ingot lengths for an invert melt orientation

Section1.Para: In contrast, a melt with an increasing annulus at the same melt rate results in a declining melt efficiency (increased specific power consumption) and an ever increasing power (current) requirement (Figure 12). An examination of the ingot top heat flux distribution throughout each melt (Figures 13 and 14) reveals that, in the case of the decreasing annulus, the peak energy flux moves outward from the central region of the ingot in the early stages of melting toward the ingot surface as melting proceeds. In contrast, for the increasing annulus case, the peak energy flux moves inward toward the center of the ingot with the outer periphery receiving a reduced energy input as melting progresses.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Energy balance at 20 % and 100 % ingot lengths for an upright melt orientation
Heat flux to ingot top at 5 % and 100 % ingot lengths for invert and upright melting

Section1.Para: Of the two situations, the decreasing annulus case must be considered to be the more robust approach. The declining input power requirement and increasing annular heat flux are both beneficial with regard to reducing the tendencies for positive segregation in the central region and white spot formation in the peripheral region of the ingot. In contrast, the increasing annulus case with its increasing current requirement and more centrally concentrated energy input as melting progresses leads to an increased possibility of segregation defects. While an invert melt practice will always yield a decreasing annulus, the specific electrode and crucible dimensions in an upright practice should be considered carefully in order to avoid an excessive increase in annulus throughout the melt. The evolving trends of a concentrated central heat input and an increasing melt current requirement increase the risk of Lorentz driven flow in the pool thereby raising the tendency toward freckle formation.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Top ingot heat flux in the outer ingot region for invert and upright melt orientations

Section1.Heading: Effect of Gap Changes during Melting
Section1.Para: Successful melting of segregation prone alloys requires good control of the arc gap between the melting electrode tip and the ingot pool surface. An examination of the heat balance at different electrode gaps illustrates what happens when changes in the gap occur. As seen in Figure 15, under melt rate control, an increase in the arc gap leads to an increased heat loss to the crown/crucible wall which tends toward a drop in melt rate. In response to this, the melt rate controller will increase the current thereby increasing the power input to try to maintain the melt rate set point. This rise in current increases the likelihood of Lorentz driven flow in the liquid pool with the attendant risk of positive segregation in the ingot.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Heat balance changes as gap arc widens from 10 mm to 20 mm under melt rate control
Heat balance changes as gap arc widens from 10 mm to 20 mm under current control

Section1.Para: The effects of a gap change when melting under constant current are illustrated in Figure 16. Once again, as the gap widens, the heat loss to the crown increases. In this case however, the controller makes no effort to alter the melt current. Assuming the furnace voltage remains constant, the power input to the furnace remains the same but is redistributed. The increased heat loss to the crown leads to a lower heat input to the electrode and ingot which in turn leads to a reduction in the observed melt rate and an increase in the specific power consumption. Thus an increase in gap for both melt rate controlled and current controlled processes results in a drop in efficiency as measured by an increase in specific power consumption. However, at constant melt rate, the increase in gap will move the process toward conditions more conducive to the formation of positive segregation while a gap increase at constant current will move the process toward the formation of white spots.

Section1.Heading: Summary
Section1.Para: The development of an electrical analog to simulate heat transfer in the VAR arc has enabled the linking of electrode and ingot models leading to development of an integrated VAR process model. The model incorporates the necessary boundary conditions so that a process engineer needs only specify operating conditions and alloy properties in order to simulate the VAR process. Simulation results presented as text, comma-separated value, and visual toolkit plot files include melt profile conditions, heat flux distributions, solidification conditions, and heat balance results. The model also includes an optimization function which executes multiple simulations over a range of melt rates to show the variation in pool depth, mushy zone depth, and local solidification times with melt rate thereby assisting in the selection of an optimum melt rate.

Model generated results can be used to prepare heat balances of the VAR process which can provide insight into the behavior of the process under different melting conditions. Such insights can provide an indication of whether the process is more or less sensitive to segregation defects as a result of process changes, whether these changes occur from practice to practice or from beginning to end of a specific practice.
